content: @Fabrizio Montesi would you consider changing (& scoping, I would think) the notation for Context.fill defined in Foundations.Context.Syntax? Currently any time I write a singleton or empty list it has to be in an extra set of parentheses (([]) or ([x])) otherwise lean thinks whatever came before is a context I'm trying to fill
I had raised this concern on the review. Maybe we can keep the bracket notation via scoping and/or making it use GetElem?
Can we keep the Context notation as-is but make it a 'second-class' citizen wrt the List notation by using scoping?
That won’t work because you will always want to use Lists in the same locations as context notation.
I suggest changing the context notation to something like K⟦ · ⟧ or Ctx⟦ · ⟧
Double brackets might be used for encodings.
It's a lot simple to add a prefix like this than tinker with notation priorities where you can't predict exactly how you mix up two different notations
Also it's useful to keep notation visually disambiguated.

mmh that'll probably look cumbersome because we'll write things like (for ctx : Context) ctx Ctx[term] instead of the current/expected ctx[term].

How about using <[ as the first bracket? so we go from c[t] to c<[t].
Oh, in that case, about how about Ctx[c | t]?

Fabrizio Montesi said:

How about using <[ as the first bracket?

this seems reasonable
i like notation as much as the next girl but is c.fill t really so bad?
or even a coercion to a function?
Avoid coercions if they are not necessary.
I like notation that introduces brackets because it removes ambiguity. If you are applying a function f to c.fill t, you'd have to write it as f (c.fill t) anyway.
